title: I cant stop feeding/inting.
body:
Guys I need help.
Recently I dropped into Bronze 2. All of my games are losses because of me. As soon as I get 1 death, when I walk back to lane and it just repeats and I'm 0/9 in no time. It's basically a problem of dying alot. How do I prevent this? I end up losing the game for my whole team.

I have this problem of not knowing what to do when behind

Try this: https://app.mobalytics.gg/r/rf/p0dv7n

https://pasteboard.co/HuBNH7O.jpg

You can see what areas you need to improve in and also gives you advice.

Only use the website since riot does not allow 3rd party programs.

There's a lot fo ways to prevent feeding.

* Firstly when you get into the game loading screen, consider what champion you are up against and what they do in lane as well as for their team. Also consider their jungler.

* Try to improve your map awareness. CS-Lookatmap-CS-lookatmap, etc. Guess where their jungler is.

* Don't fight a fed opponent (Sun Tzu: "Don't fight a stronger enemy"), unless you are sure their spells are on cooldown and none of their teammates are nearby. This comes with experience. And fed = their level+their items they have in inventory. Check this with TAB.

* Also use TAB in-game to see what they are building. Try to itemise correctly against them and their team. For example if you are a top lane tank and they have a Garen + Jarvan jungler, you'll be buying armour items.

* If behind, focus on farming only. Remember that farm gives you experience and therefore levels, and the higher your level in game, the more damage you do.

* Don't forget to buy a control ward, very useful to see if someone is coming or not. Find a good moment to place it.

Just a few basic tips. Good luck!

Whenever i die, I always go to place a deep ward just in case I die again to the jungler. I feel like this is what could get me killed/gets me killed.

but mostly my lack of knowledge in game

First step is admitting that you are clearly doing something wrong. Most summoner would not admit their faults but instead blame everyone else. So I congratulate you for acknowledging your faults and taking the right first step to hopefully improving your game.
